an4.62:1.1: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
an4.62:2.1: “Householder, these four kinds of happiness can be earned by a layperson who enjoys sensual pleasures, depending on time and occasion.
an4.62:2.3: The happiness of ownership, using wealth, debtlessness, and blamelessness.
an4.62:3.1: And what is the happiness of ownership?
an4.62:3.2: It’s when a gentleman owns legitimate wealth that he has earned by his own efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow.
an4.62:3.3: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
an4.62:3.4: This is called ‘the happiness of ownership’.
an4.62:4.1: And what is the happiness of using wealth?
an4.62:4.2: It’s when a gentleman uses his legitimate wealth, and makes merit with it.
an4.62:4.3: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
an4.62:4.4: This is called ‘the happiness of using wealth’.
an4.62:5.1: And what is the happiness of debtlessness?
an4.62:5.2: It’s when a gentleman owes no debt, large or small, to anyone.
an4.62:5.3: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
an4.62:5.4: This is called ‘the happiness of debtlessness’.
an4.62:6.1: And what is the happiness of blamelessness?
an4.62:6.2: It’s when a noble disciple has blameless conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.
an4.62:6.3: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
an4.62:6.4: This is called ‘the happiness of blamelessness’.
an4.62:6.5: These four kinds of happiness can be earned by a layperson who enjoys sensual pleasures, depending on time and occasion.
an4.62:7.2: and the extra happiness of possession,
an4.62:7.3: a mortal enjoying the happiness of using wealth,
an4.62:8.1: Seeing clearly, a clever person knows
an4.62:8.3: the other kind is not worth a sixteenth part
